contentBody.bodyText:
Commerce

Marcelline Soton Akouegninou, Benin, clothes shop

Marcelline is 32. She has been selling fabrics and jewellery locally for about four years. As there are no similar traders nearby, her business has a good turnover. She buys her stock in the capital's international market and wants the loan to purchase more stock so she can meet customer demand. This loan will help boost her business and generate more profit, so she can continue to pay her children's school fees.
Read Marcelline's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Colette Dassi-Vera Woussa, Benin, clothes shop

After leaving school, Colette, 38, trained in haute couture and then became a seamstress. Her studio opened 15 years ago and she now has eight apprentices who assist her in making her clothes. She buys her stock in the capital's international market. Colette has requested a loan to help purchase supplies for her clothes shop. She will be able to increase her profits as a result.
Read Colette's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Maura Estela Sánchez, Ecuador, greengrocer

Maura is 54 and has six adult children. Maura married when she was 20 and for many years she and her husband grew tomatoes, cucumbers and maize. They bought land and built their own home. She is now divorced from her husband and lives with two of her children, who both contribute to household expenses. Maura sells produce at the weekly farmers' markets. She has asked for a loan to buy produce, as she does not grow enough of her own.
Read Maura's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Cyrell Reyes, Philippines, vehicle repair shop

Vehicle-repair shop owner Cyrell is 37. Her husband Reynan, a professional mechanic, is 34. Cyrell runs the business and Reynan repairs the vehicles. The customers are mostly motorcab, jeepney and car owners looking for high-quality repairs and maintenance for their vehicles. Cyrell ensures that the equipment and machinery, as well as other tools her husband uses, are in good condition. She also hires two close relatives to help. The loan will be used to acquire more tools and equipment for the repair shop.
Read Cyrell's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Adjo Therese Gnamie, Togo, hairdressing salon

Hairdresser Adjo is 39, married with three children, and has owned her salon, Eclat D'or, since 2006. She employs one person and also sells hair accessories and beauty products. Now, due to popular demand, she wants to broaden her product range to include school stationery and supplies. Her aim is to earn enough to enrol her children in the best schools.
Read Adjo's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Dovi Adoufa, Togo, market stallholder

Dovi has sold basic grains in the market since 1998. She is 38 and married with four children aged 7-18, all of whom are in full-time education. Dovi buys cereals (maize, millet and beans) from wholesale suppliers and resells them at the local market. She employs two full-time staff. One of Dovi's biggest problems is the difficulty and cost of transporting the grains, so she hopes to earn enough to buy her own vehicle. This loan will enable her to buy larger quantities of grain.
Read Dovi's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Issaka Komandan, Togo, market stallholder

Issaka, 27, is married to a retailer and has two young children. Issaka has been buying and selling fresh water in bags since 2006, working with two suppliers. He wants to increase his stock of merchandise to help him find new clients, enabling him to finance his children's education and contribute to building his own house. This loan is to purchase 450 bags of pure water, four coolers and accessories.
Read Issaka's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Lea Delos Reyes, Philippines, recycling

Lea, 39, is married to 38-year-old company driver Ricardo and has five children aged 7-18. Lea buys plastic bottles, cans and sacks from her neighbours and other rubbish collectors, then re-sells them on a wholesale basis after a week or two of collecting. Lea has a regular buyer of scrap materials from whom she can earn a small profit and she also employs two part-time workers. She wants additional working capital to buy more recyclable items from her neighbours.
Read Lea's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Farming and food production

Mean Hem, Cambodia, fishing

Mean is 41 years old and a widow with five children. She has been running a business buying and selling fish, snails and water spinach for the past 12 years. She uses a boat to transport them from the nearby flooded forest, before selling them to a middleman. She will use the loan to buy her own boat and fishing equipment.
Read Mean's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Houch Pat, Cambodia, farming

Houch, 53, and her husband, By Chhoum, farm 10 hectares of rice paddy. The land yields around two tonnes of rice per hectare. To supplement their income they also grow chillis. Part of their land will be cultivated twice a year when the government finishes building the irrigation system next year. This loan will be used to buy fertiliser and insecticide.
Read Houch's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Darwin Castillo Picoita, Ecuador, farming

Darwin specialises in the production of greenhouse tomatoes and coffee. He relies on loans to help his farming - large investments are needed at particular times of the year when there may be weeks or even months until the harvest comes in. Darwin has asked for a loan to buy seeds, fertiliser and prepare the land for growing coffee. Most of the weeding and preparing of the coffee bushes has to be done by hand, so he often hires labourers.
Read Darwin's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Angélica María Tene Pintado, Ecuador, raising poultry

Angélica is 23 and married with a three-year-old daughter. When she's not raising and selling chickens and guinea pigs on land next to her home, she studies Business Administration. She sells the chickens and guinea pigs directly to consumers because she can make more money that way. The loan would be used to buy chicks and feed in bulk, and make improvements to the animals' housing.
Read Angélica's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Zejna Hibic, Bosnia-Herzegovina, farmer

Zejna is 60 years old and makes her living as a farmer, growing and selling vegetables such as peas, potatoes and onions. She also has a cow, whose milk she sells or uses to make cheese. Zejna wants to increase the amount of milk she sells by buying another cow. But first, she needs to renovate and improve the barn where the animals are kept.
Read Zejna's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

Arts and crafts

Edita Devic, Bosnia-Herzegovina, artist

Edita Devic, 56, is a well-established artist, who makes a living from selling landscapes, portraits and still lifes. The business brings her a good regular income that enables her to cover most household expenses, including the college fees for her two student children. The loan would help her purchase new equipment, including brushes, canvas and paints.
Read Edita's story and learn how you can help similar entrepreneurs

inBodyVideoDelegate.caption: Andrew Mitchell insists CCTV clears him over Plebgate

pages.trailText: CARE International has helped thousands of people in the developing world put their business ideas into practice, but more still need your help. Hear their stories and find out how you can encourage their businesses to prosper below
